defs.etymology: From Latin a.

text: The first letter of the Portuguese alphabet, written in the Latin script.

words: with diacritics: ã, â, à, á

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese a, from Latin illa (with the disappearance of an initial l; compare Spanish la).

examples: Então, como foi a última festinha de Slughorn?So, how was the last Slughorn's little party?
So, how was the last Slughorn's little party?
Entregou a foto rasgada, [...]He handed over the torn photograph, [...]
He handed over the torn photograph, [...]

text: Her, it (as a direct object; as an indirect object, see lhe; after prepositions, see ela).
examples: Encontrei-a na rua. ― I met her/it on the street.

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese a, from Latin ad (“to”) and ab (“from, away, by”).

text: with; by means of, using as an instrument or means
with; on, using as a medium or fuel
by, using the specified measurement; in the specified quantity
(preceded and followed by the same word) by, indicates a steady progression
in the style or manner of; a la
(limited use, see usage notes) at, during the specified period
(rare except in set terms) at; in, indicates a location or position
indicates the direct object, mainly to avoid confusion when it, the subject, or both are displaced, or for emphasis
(Portugal, followed by a verb in the infinitive form) forms the present participle; in Brazil, the gerund is used instead
(followed by an infinitive or present passive) to, forms the future participle
examples: Deixe-me mostrar a você...Let me show it to you...
Let me show it to you...
Não é bonito dizer isso a uma pessoa.It's not nice to say that to a person.
It's not nice to say that to a person.
Dê-o a mim. ― Give it to me.
Meu coração pertence a você. ― My heart belongs to you.
Synonym: para
Vamos a Paris! ― Let’s go to Paris!
Synonyms: para, até
A vila fica a onze milhas ― The village is eleven miles away.
Comunicação à distância. ― Communication at a distance.
Mataram o cão a pauladas. ― They bludgeoned the dog to death.
A cavalo. ― On horseback.
Livro escrito a lápis. ― A book written with a pencil.
Synonyms: com, por meio de
Quadro pintado a óleo. ― A painting painted with oil.
Fornalha a carvão. ― Coal furnace.
É mais barato comprar comida ao quilo. ― It is cheaper to by food by the kilogram.
Os fracassos ocorrem às dezenas. ― Failures occur by the dozen.
Calma lá. Resolva o problema passo a passo. ― Easy there. Solve the problem step by step.
Synonym: por
Ele puxou o temperamento ao pai. ― He inherited his temperament from his father.
Camarão à grega. ― Greek-style shrimp.
Synonym: ao modo de
Dormimos à noite. ― We sleep at night.
O filme começa às duas horas. ― The film starts at two o’clock.
Synonyms: em, de
Isso fica à frente do altar. ― This stays in front of the altar.
Synonym: em
A mim ele não engana. ― He doesn’t deceive me.
Estou a preparar a canja ― I am preparing the chicken soup
Um trabalho a ser feito. ― A job to be done.
Nada a fazer. ― Nothing to be done.
Synonyms: para, por
A, tudo bem então. Oh, all right then.
Oh, all right then.

defs.etymology: From homophone há
From homophone à

text: The fifteenth letter of the Portuguese alphabet, written in the Latin script.

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese o (compare Galician o), from Vulgar Latin lo, *illu, from Latin illum, from ille (with an initial l having disappeared; compare Spanish lo).

text: o m (feminine a, masculine plural os, feminine plural as)
examples: Não vi o tempo passar.I didn't notice the time passing.
I didn't notice the time passing.

text: him, it (as a direct object; as an indirect object, see lhe; after prepositions, see ele).
examples: Não o perdoou por abandonar o serviço em vez de seguir você.She didn't forgive him for abandoning his service instead of following you.
She didn't forgive him for abandoning his service instead of following you.
Por que, então, ela o conduzira àquele lugar?Why, then, did she lead him to that place?
Why, then, did she lead him to that place?

text: third-person singular (ele and ela, also used with você and others) present indicative of estar
second-person singular (tu, sometimes used with você) affirmative imperative of estar
examples:
Está na hora de testarmos os nossos talentos no mundo real, você não acha?
It's time to test our talents in the real world, don't you think?
It's time to test our talents in the real world, don't you think?
Você está me chamando de maluco?Are you calling me crazy?
Are you calling me crazy?

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese do, from de (“of”) + o (“the”). Akin to Spanish del and French du.
Merger of Old Portuguese por, from Vulgar Latin *por, from Latin prō (“for”) (with metathetic shift due to per), and Old Portuguese per, from Latin per (“through, by”).

text: for (indicates something given in an exchange)
by (through the action or presence of)
by (indicates the creator of a work)
by (using the rules or logic of)
by; in the name of (indicates an oath)
per; a; each (expresses the ratio of units)
through (entering and then leaving; being the medium of)
around; about; near (in the vicinity of)
around; about; approximately (close in quantity, amount or value to)
(in the formula “X por Y”, where X is a clause and Y the infinitive of the verb in the clause, or of a synonym) for its own sake; without a motive

words: (indicates an exchange): em troca de, a troco de (especially in figurative usage)
(using the rules or logic of): de acordo com, segundo
(in the name of): em nome de
(in the vicinity of): perto de, ao redor de
(approximately): perto de, ao redor de, mais ou menos, aproximadamente, cerca de

examples: Faça isso por mim.Do this for me.
Do this for me.
Espero por uma resposta.I wait for an answer.
I wait for an answer.
Eu farei de tudo por uma cópia deste livro.I will do anything for a copy of this book.
I will do anything for a copy of this book.
Esperei por uma semana.I waited for one week.
I waited for one week.
Ela deu sua bicicleta pela minha.She gave her bicycle for mine.
She gave her bicycle for mine.
A manutenção é feita por engenheiros.The maintenance is carried out by engineers.
The maintenance is carried out by engineers.
Os livros por Tolkien são ótimos.Books by Tolkien are great.
Books by Tolkien are great.
Pela lei, deveríamos estar presos.By law, we should be in jail.
By law, we should be in jail.
oito por sete ― eights times seven; eights by seven
Venceremos essa batalha, pelo rei!We shall win this battle, by the king!
We shall win this battle, by the king!
Tome uma pílula por dia.Take one pill per day.
Take one pill per day.
Vinte por quatro é cinco.Twenty by four is five.
Twenty by four is five.
Ainda passaríamos por muitos túneis antes de chegarmos.We would still pass through many tunnels before we arrived.
We would still pass through many tunnels before we arrived.
Passar por uma situação difícil.Go through a difficult situation.
Go through a difficult situation.
O tesouro foi encontrado por Dudinka.The treasure was found around Dudinka.
The treasure was found around Dudinka.
Gostamos de passear por aí.We like to stroll around.
We like to stroll around.
O preço de um prato nos mercados daqui é por vinte euros.The price of a plate in the local markets is around twenty euros.
The price of a plate in the local markets is around twenty euros.
Partiremos pelas dez.We will leave around ten.
We will leave around ten.
Esse tipo de ruína é encontrado pela Escócia.This type of ruin is found throughout Scotland.
This type of ruin is found throughout Scotland.
Somos pela melhora da educação.We are for the improvement of education.
We are for the improvement of education.
Eu falei aquilo só por falar.I said that just to say something.
I said that just to say something.

text: Obsolete spelling of pôr, now a common misspelling

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese os, from Vulgar Latin *los, from Latin illōs.

examples: Está na hora de testarmos os nossos talentos no mundo real, você não acha?It's time to test the talents of ours in the real world, don't you think?
It's time to test the talents of ours in the real world, don't you think?
Você notou os cabelos dela, são negros e brilhantes e macios...You noticed her hair , it's dark and brilliant and soft...
You noticed her hair , it's dark and brilliant and soft...
Devíamos fechar os olhos dele.We should close his eyes .
We should close his eyes .

text: third-person plural direct objective personal pronoun; them
examples: Encontrei-os na rua.I met them at the street.
I met them at the street.
Synonyms:  lhes, eles,  elas

defs.etymology: See the etymology of the corresponding lemma form.
From Old Portuguese mas, from Latin magis (“more”), from Proto-Indo-European *meǵh₂- (“great”). Doublet of mais.

text: but (introduces a clause that contradicts the implications of the previous clause)
but (introduces the correct information for something that was denied in the previous clause)
but ... really; of course; no wonder (introduces the cause of the previous clause, with the implication that the result was expected given this cause)
examples: O livro é curto, mas bom.The book is short, but good.
The book is short, but good.
Somos preguiçosos mas fazemos o que precisa de ser feito.We are lazy but we do what needs to be done.
We are lazy but we do what needs to be done.
Synonyms:  só que,  contudo,  no entanto,  porém,  todavia,  entretanto
Fomos recebidos não com aplausos, mas pedradas.We were not received with applause, but [with] rocks.
We were not received with applause, but [with] rocks.
Todos alunos reprovaram em matemática, mas ninguém estudou mesmo.All students flunked mathematics, but no one studied really.
All students flunked mathematics, but no one studied really.
Mas que porcaria!What the heck!
What the heck!
Mas que diabos vocês estão fazendo aqui?What the hell are you doing here?
What the hell are you doing here?

text: (colloquial) emphasises a previous clause, adverb or adjective; really; and how
examples: Este livro é bom, mas bom mesmo.This book is good, really good.
This book is good, really good.
Os ladrões correram, mas correram.The thieves ran, and how they ran.
The thieves ran, and how they ran.
Synonyms: e como, e

text: but (an instance of proclaiming an exception)
examples: Quero que você termine isso, sem mas nem porquês.I want you to finish this, no buts or whys.
I want you to finish this, no buts or whys.

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese en, from Latin in (“in”), from Proto-Italic *en, from Proto-Indo-European *h₁én (“in”). Doublet of in.

text: on; on top of (located just above the surface of)
in; into; inside (towards the inside of)
indicates the target of an action
in (immediately after a period of time)
in; during (within a period of time)
in (indicates means, medium, format, genre or instrumentality)
in (indicates a language, script, tone etc. of writing, speaking etc.)
(slang) indicates that the object deserves a given punishment
examples: Estou na minha casa.I’m in my house.
I’m in my house.
Encontraram umas moedas no baú.They found some coins inside the chest.
They found some coins inside the chest.

Então o sorriso reapareceu em seu rosto [...]
Then the smile reappeared on his face [...]
Then the smile reappeared on his face [...]
O livro está na mesa.The book is on the table.
The book is on the table.
Os soldados estão na Crimeia.The soldiers are in Crimea.
The soldiers are in Crimea.
Só três jogadores ainda estão nesse time.Only three players are still in this team.
Only three players are still in this team.
A água entrou em várias casas.The water got into various houses.
The water got into various houses.
Quero dar um soco na tua cara.I want to punch you in the face.
I want to punch you in the face.
Mete um processo neles.Shove a lawsuit down their throats.
Shove a lawsuit down their throats.
Ela não passou em inglês.She didn’t pass in English.
She didn’t pass in English.
Entraremos em contato com você em duas semanas.We will get in contact with you in two weeks.
We will get in contact with you in two weeks.
O jornal será publicado no dia cinco.The newspaper will be published on the fifth.
The newspaper will be published on the fifth.
Estamos em perigo!We’re in danger!
We’re in danger!
Fomos pagos em moeda estrangeira.We were paid in foreign currency.
We were paid in foreign currency.
Li um livro em holandês.I read a book in Dutch.
I read a book in Dutch.
A moça em preto.The lady in black.
The lady in black.
Cadeia nele!He should be in jail!
He should be in jail!

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese as, from Latin illās (with an initial l having disappeared; compare Spanish las).

examples: Todos olharam para trás ao alcançarem as árvores.Everyone looked behind when they reached the trees.
Everyone looked behind when they reached the trees.
Mandaram lacrar todas as saídas e não deixar ninguém...They ordered me to seal all the exits and not to let anyone...
They ordered me to seal all the exits and not to let anyone...

text: (third person personal) them (as a direct object; the corresponding indirect object is lhes; the form used after prepositions is elas).
examples: Encontrei-as na rua. ― I met them in the street.
Synonyms: las, nas

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese mais, from Latin magis (“more”). Doublet of mas. Displaced collateral (Old Portuguese) form chus.

text: used to form the comparative of adjectives and adverbs; more; -er
preceded by the definitive article, used to form the superlative of adjectives and adverbs; most; -est
more (to a greater degree or extent)
(in negative sentences) any more, any longer
examples:
O Tejo é mais bello que o rio que corre pela minha aldeia
The Tagus is more beautiful than the river that flows through my village
The Tagus is more beautiful than the river that flows through my village
Então continuaram a estudar enquanto o céu lá fora se tornava gradualmente mais escuro.Then they continued to study while the sky outside was becoming gradually darker.
Then they continued to study while the sky outside was becoming gradually darker.

[…] , quanto maior o diâmetro axonal, mais rapidamente ele conduz impulsos.
 […] , the greater the axonal diameter, the faster it conducts impulses.
[…] , the greater the axonal diameter, the faster it conducts impulses.

[…] , num final de dia muito frio, o mais frio desse ano.
 […] , in the end of a very cold day, the coldest this year.
[…] , in the end of a very cold day, the coldest this year.

Então eu corri mais, esperando dar tempo de passar.
So I ran more, hoping there would be enough time to go through.
So I ran more, hoping there would be enough time to go through.
Ele tem razão, eu não quero mais dormir no mesmo dormitório que ele, ele é doido.He is right, I don't want to sleep in the same dormitory as him any more, he is crazy.
He is right, I don't want to sleep in the same dormitory as him any more, he is crazy.
Não gosto mais de morar aquiI don’t like living here any more
I don’t like living here any more

text: (arithmetic) plus (sum of the previous one and the following one)
examples: Eu mais ela vamos 'tar casandoShe and I are getting married.
She and I are getting married.
Synonym: sinal de mais

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese muito, from Latin multus (“much; many”), from the Proto-Indo-European *ml̥tos (“crumbled, crumpled”, past passive participle). Compare Italian molto, Romanian mult, and Spanish mucho.

text: muito m (plural muitos, feminine muita, feminine plural muitas)
much; many; a lot of; lots of
too much; too many (an excessive amount of)
examples: Tenho muitas coisas para fazer.I have many things to do.
I have many things to do.
Choveu muita água.It rained a lot.
It rained a lot.
Synonyms: bastante,  maningue
Não gosto daqui, tem muita gente.I don’t like it here, there are too many people.
I don’t like it here, there are too many people.
Synonym: demais

text: very; a lot; very much (to a great extent or degree)
examples: Gosto muito de você.I like you very much.
I like you very much.
Está muito frio.It is very cold.
It is very cold.
Synonyms: bastante,  maningue,  bem,  mui

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese isto, from Latin istud, neuter of iste (“that”).

text: this (the thing being discussed; the current situation)
(obsolete, literature) this sentence, this word, this dictum
examples: Te entregarei isto, acho que vale algo.I will hand this over to you, I think it’s worth something.
I will hand this over to you, I think it’s worth something.
Isto não é fácil.This is not easy.
This is not easy.
— Você é o filho da Mariana? — Isto.“Are you Mariana’s son?” “That’s right.”
“Are you Mariana’s son?” “That’s right.”
Eles perderam! Isto!They lost! Yeah!
They lost! Yeah!

text: first-person singular (eu) present indicative of estar; "I am"
examples:
Estou perfeitamente satisfeito com a segurança que tenho [...]
I am perfectly satisfied with the security I have [...]
I am perfectly satisfied with the security I have [...]
Confiem em mim. Sei o que estou fazendo...Trust me. I know what I'm doing...
Trust me. I know what I'm doing...

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese fazer, from Latin facere, present active infinitive of faciō (“I do; I make”), from Proto-Italic *fakjō, from Proto-Indo-European *dʰeh₁- (“to put, impose, do, make, place, set”). Compare Spanish hacer, French faire, Italian fare.

text: fazer (first-person singular present indicative faço, past participle feito)
(takes a reflexive pronoun, transitive with de) to play; to pretend to be
(transitive) to turn; to reach an age; to have a birthday
(ditransitive, with the indirect object taking por) to sell for a given price (usually to make cheaper in a bargain)
(transitive) to attend a course (academic or not)
(transitive, impersonal) to be; to occur (said of a weather phenomenon)
examples: A minha mãe fez este vestido para mim. ― My mother made this dress for me.
Synonyms: produzir, confeccionar
Aquele homem fez um crime terrível. ― That man committed a horrible crime.
Eu respondi fazendo um gesto afirmativo. ― I answered by making an affirmative gesture.
Synonyms: executar, realizar, praticar
A explosão fez cair alguns prédios. ― The explosion made some buildings fall.
Já fiz a cama hoje. ― I've already made my bed today.
Synonyms: arrumar, organizar
Nós fizemos o almoço juntos! ― We made lunch together!
Synonyms: preparar, cozinhar
Eu fiz-me de João, a minha irmã fez-se de Maria. ― I played Hansel, my sister played Gretel.
fazer-se de bobo ― to play the fool
Os gêmeos fizeram quinze anos no mês passado. ― The twins turned fifteen last month.
Synonym: completar
Se você comprar dois, faço por trinta dólares. ― If you buy two, I can sell them for thirty dollars.
Faço inglês. ― I take an English course.
Synonym: cursar
Faz duas horas que meu tio chegou. ― Two hours have passed since my uncle arrived.
Aqui faz sempre sol. ― It’s always sunny here.

text: first-person plural (nós) present indicative of ir
first-person plural (nós) present subjunctive of ir
first-person plural (nós) affirmative imperative of ir
first-person plural (nós) negative imperative of ir
(auxiliary, followed by infinitive) forms the analytic first-person plural imperative: let’s
examples: Vamos almoçar.Let’s have lunch.
Let’s have lunch.

defs.etymology:
From Old Portuguese seer, with forms from multiple sources:
Latin sum (“to be, to exist”), from Proto-Italic *ezom, from Proto-Indo-European *h₁ésti (“I am, I exist”).
Latin sedeō (“to sit”), from Proto-Italic *sedēō, from Proto-Indo-European *sed-.
Latin sedeō: personal and impersonal infinitives (sedēre), gerund, present subjunctive, affirmative imperative
Latin sum: present indicative, imperfect indicative, preterite indicative, pluperfect indicative, imperfect subjunctive, future subjunctive
Vulgar Latin *sonō: souVulgar Latin *sutis: sois
Vulgar Latin *sonō: sou
Vulgar Latin *sutis: sois
later developments: past participle, future indicative, conditional, negative imperative

text: ser (first-person singular present indicative sou, past participle sido)
(copulative) to be (to have the given quality), especially a quality that is intrinsic or not expected to change, contrasting with estar which denotes a temporary quality
(transitive) to be (to be an example or type of, or the same as)
(auxiliary with a verb in the past participle) to be (forms the passive voice)
(impersonal) to be (indicates a point in time)
(transitive with em or another locational preposition) to be in (to be located in)
(transitive with de) to be from (to have as one’s place of origin)
(transitive with de) to be (someone’s); to belong to
(transitive or auxiliary with para or de and a verb in the personal infinitive) to be for; to be to (to have as its purpose)
(impersonal, auxiliary with para and a verb in the personal infinitive) to be supposed to; should (introduces an expected or demanded action)
(transitive) to be; to cost (to be worth a given amount of money)
(intransitive) to happen; to take place; to occur
(transitive with por or a favor de or contra) to be against or in favour of

words: (forms the passive voice): any reflexive pronoun
(to be located in): ficar em, localizar-se em
(to have as its purpose): servir para
(to happen): acontecer, haver, ocorrer, ter, produzir-se, realizar-se, sobrevir, suceder

examples: Ela está bonita, mas não é bonita.She is looking beautiful, but she is not beautiful.
She is looking beautiful, but she is not beautiful.
Pessoas são mamíferos.People are mammals.
People are mammals.
A soma de um e dois é três.The sum of one and two is three.
The sum of one and two is three.
O carro foi vendido pelo seu antigo dono.The car was sold by its previous owner.
The car was sold by its previous owner.
Espero que os criminosos sejam punidos.I hope the criminals are punished.
I hope the criminals are punished.
Que horas são?What time is it?
What time is it?
São cinco horas.It is five o’clock.
It is five o’clock.
Minha casa é num bairro pobre.My house is in a poor neighbourhood.
My house is in a poor neighbourhood.
Onde são essas cidades?Where are these cities?
Where are these cities?
Esses equipamentos são da Alemanha.These pieces of equipment are from Germany.
These pieces of equipment are from Germany.
Nenhum de nós é de um país estrangeiro.None of us is from a foreign country.
None of us is from a foreign country.
Essa casa é do prefeito.This house belongs to the mayor.
This house belongs to the mayor.
Não mexa em nada que não for seu.Don’t touch anything that is not yours.
Don’t touch anything that is not yours.
Esse tipo de faca é para cortar tomates.This type of knife is for cutting tomatoes.
This type of knife is for cutting tomatoes.
Não sei porque está demorando, já era para o filme ter começado.I don’t know why it is taking so long, the film should have started already.
I don’t know why it is taking so long, the film should have started already.
É para comermos toda a carne.We are supposed to eat all the meat.
We are supposed to eat all the meat.
Duas maçãs são dez centavos.Two apples are ten cents.
Two apples are ten cents.
O que será, será.Whatever happens happens.
Whatever happens happens.
Quando é seu aniversário?When is your birthday?
When is your birthday?
Alguns foram contra a guerra, mas a maioria foi a favor.Some were against the war, but most were in favour.
Some were against the war, but most were in favour.
O mal não é.Evil does not exist.
Evil does not exist.
Eu é que vim.I’m the one who came here.
I’m the one who came here.

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese todo, from Latin tōtus (“all; everything”).

text: (Brazil, slang) everyone; all (all people in general or in a specific group)
examples: O dinheiro não é tudo. ― Money isn’t everything.
Tá tudo louco aqui! ― Everyone is nuts here!
As bolas vermelhas tão tudo dentro do saco ― The red balls are all in the bag.
Synonyms: todos, todo mundo

defs.etymology:
From Old Portuguese porque, corresponding to por (“for”) +‎ que (“that”).
Cognate with Galician porque, Spanish porque, Catalan perquè, French parce que and Italian perché.

text: because; for (introduces an explanation to the claim in the previous clause)
examples: Aproveita tua vida porque ela é curta!Enjoy your life because it is short!
Enjoy your life because it is short!
Synonyms: pois, que
Porque é o céu azul?Why is the sky blue?
Why is the sky blue?
Synonym:  por que

text: second-person singular (tu) present indicative of estar

defs.etymology: Syncope of vosmecê, elision of vossemecê, contraction of Old Portuguese vossa mercee (today's mercê) from Latin vostra and mercēs. Compare with the Spanish usted (from vuestra merced, also literally "your mercy") and Catalan vostè.

text: (formal, semi-formal, or offensive in Portugal, informal or semi-formal in Brazil) second-person singular personal pronoun; you

words: (second-person singular personal pronoun): o senhor, tu
(indefinite pronoun): reflexive third-person pronouns (se, si, consigo)

examples:
Pensei que você tivesse dito que ela estava só mandando você escrever!
I thought that you had said that she was just ordering you to write!
I thought that you had said that she was just ordering you to write!
Você pode levar um cavalo até a água, mas não pode fazê-lo beber.You can take a horse to the water, but you can’t make it drink.
You can take a horse to the water, but you can’t make it drink.

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese teer, from earlier Old Portuguese tẽer, from proto-Ibero-Romance tener < tenere, from Latin tenēre, from Proto-Italic *tenēō, stative from Proto-Indo-European *ten- (“to stretch, draw”).

text: ter (first-person singular present indicative tenho, past participle tido)
(auxiliary with de or que and a verb in the infinitive) must; to have to
(impersonal, transitive) there be (to exist, physically or abstractly)
(copulative or transitive with por or como) to consider (assign some quality to)
(transitive with com) to go to; to interact with somebody

words: (to give birth to): dar à luz, parir

examples: Eu tenho uma bela casa.I have a beautiful house.
I have a beautiful house.
Eu tenho uma bela casa.I've got a beautiful house.
I've got a beautiful house.
Os caridosos sempre ajudam os que não têm.The charitable always help those who don’t have enough.
The charitable always help those who don’t have enough.
Esta frase tem cinco palavras.This sentence has five words.
This sentence has five words.
Lanças têm cabos compridos.Spears have long shafts.
Spears have long shafts.
Esse livro tem dono.This book has an owner.
This book has an owner.
Tenho três irmãs.I have three sisters.
I have three sisters.
O senhor tem sua carteira?Do you have your wallet on you?
Do you have your wallet on you?
Tenho quarenta anos.I am forty years old.
I am forty years old.
Tenho 1,78 m de altura.I am 1.78 m tall.
I am 1.78 m tall.
Esta caneta tem dez centímetros.This pen is ten centimeters long.
This pen is ten centimeters long.
Este jogo não tem graça.This game isn’t fun.”)
This game isn’t fun.
As palavras que dizes têm significado.The words you say have meaning.
The words you say have meaning.
Tu tens um resfriado.You have a cold.
You have a cold.
Temos uma partida de xadrez daqui a uma semana.We have a chess match in a week.
We have a chess match in a week.
Ainda não tive esse mês.I still haven’t received my wage this month.
I still haven’t received my wage this month.

Sinto muito ter de contradizê-la, Minerva, mas, como pode ver no meu bilhete, Harry tem obtido resultados muito fracos nas minhas aulas...I'm sorry to contradict you, Minerva, but, as you can see in my note, Harry has obtained very weak results in my classes...
I'm sorry to contradict you, Minerva, but, as you can see in my note, Harry has obtained very weak results in my classes...
Nós tínhamos comido bolo.We had eaten cake.
We had eaten cake.
Tenho comido muita carne ultimamente.I have been eating a lot of meat lately.
I have been eating a lot of meat lately.
Eu o teria comprado, se tivesse dinheiro.I would have bought it, if I had money.
I would have bought it, if I had money.
Amanhã terá aula.There will be class tomorrow.
There will be class tomorrow.
Tem países em guerra naquela região.There are countries at war in that region.
There are countries at war in that region.
A vaca terá um bezerro.The cow will give birth to a calf.
The cow will give birth to a calf.
Estou tendo gêmeos!I'm having twins!
I'm having twins!
Todos têm João por inteligente.Everyone considers John to be intelligent.
Everyone considers John to be intelligent.
João o tinha como amigo.John considered him a friend.
John considered him a friend.
Vá ter com a formiga, ó preguiçoso; considera os seus caminhos e sê sábio.Go to the ant, you sluggard; consider its ways and be wise.
Go to the ant, you sluggard; consider its ways and be wise.

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese quen, from Latin quem, accusative case of interrogative quis (“who?”) and relative quī (“who”).

text: (indefinite) those who; people who; anyone who

words: (those who): aqueles que, pessoas que, os que

examples: Quem viu o novo filme?Who has seen the new film?
Who has seen the new film?
Não me lembro do nome de quem me ligou.I don’t remember the name of the person who called me.
I don’t remember the name of the person who called me.
Deus ajuda quem se ajuda.God helps those who help themselves.
God helps those who help themselves.
Quem quiser sair, que o faça.Anyone who wants to leave, do it.
Anyone who wants to leave, do it.

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese dizer, from Latin dīcere, present active participle of dīcō, from Proto-Italic *deikō, from Proto-Indo-European *déyḱti (“to show, point out”).

text: dizer (first-person singular present indicative digo, past participle dito)
to discern; to tell to distinguish
examples: Abra a boca e diga aaaaa.Open your mouth and say aaaaah.
Open your mouth and say aaaaah.
Ele disse “eu nunca fiz isso”.He said “I’ve never done this”
He said “I’ve never done this”

Não é bonito dizer isso a uma pessoa.
It's not nice to say that to a person.
It's not nice to say that to a person.
A placa diz que não podemos entrar.The sign says that we can’t go in.
The sign says that we can’t go in.

Era difícil dizer se a professora os ouvira, pois seu rosto estava oculto pelas sombras.
It was difficult to tell whether the teacher had heard them, because her face was hidden by the shadows.
It was difficult to tell whether the teacher had heard them, because her face was hidden by the shadows.
Vamos à festa para comer... Digo, celebrar.We're going to the party to eat... I mean, to celebrate.
We're going to the party to eat... I mean, to celebrate.
“Ir para o céu” você diz... morrer?By “go to heaven” you mean... to die?
By “go to heaven” you mean... to die?

text: First-person singular (eu) imperfect indicative of estar
Third-person singular (ele, ela, also used with tu and você?) imperfect indicative of estar
examples: Eu estava na esperança de encontrá-lo antes do jantar!I was hoping to meet you before dinner!
I was hoping to meet you before dinner!

Pensei que você tivesse dito que ela estava só mandando você escrever!
I thought that you have said that she was just ordering you to write!
I thought that you have said that she was just ordering you to write!

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese mesmo, from earlier Old Portuguese meesmo, from Vulgar Latin of Iberia *medesmo, from proto-Romanic forms as *medessimu, from *medissimu, from *medipsimu, from Vulgar Latin *metipsimus,  from a previous *metipsissīmus, derived from Latin -met (emphatic suffix) + ipse (“himself”) + -issimus (superlative suffix).. Compare with Spanish mismo, French même.

examples: O mesmo ocorreu hoje.The same happened today.
The same happened today.

text: mesmo m (feminine singular mesma, masculine plural mesmos, feminine plural mesmas, comparable)
examples: Vi a mesma árvore novamente.I saw the same tree again.
I saw the same tree again.
Tens os mesmos olhos que eu.You have the same eyes as I do.
You have the same eyes as I do.
Synonym: igual
O cidadão mesmo que o prendeu.The citizen himself arrested him.
The citizen himself arrested him.
Eu mesmo fiz o bolo.I baked the cake myself.
I baked the cake myself.
O que eu vi é esse mesmo.The one I saw is this one indeed.
The one I saw is this one indeed.
Synonym: próprio

text: even (implying an extreme example in the case mentioned)
(following an adverb denoting time) intensifies the fact that an act occurred, occurs or will occur during that time; right; precisely
(following an adverb denoting a location) emphasises the preciseness of a location; right
(sentence-final) again (used to ask for forgotten information)
examples: O que quero mesmo é tomar um banho.What I want really is to have a shower.
What I want really is to have a shower.
É mesmo rara esta ave?Is this bird really rare?
Is this bird really rare?
Mesmo?Really?
Really?
Synonyms: de fato, na realidade, realmente, verdadeiramente
A vida é assim mesmo.That's just how life is.
That's just how life is.
Mesmo as aranhas menores podem matar.Even the smallest spiders can kill.
Even the smallest spiders can kill.
Synonyms: até, até mesmo
Amanhã mesmo enviar-lhe-ei o documento.I will send him the document precisely tomorrow.
I will send him the document precisely tomorrow.
Farei agora mesmo.I will do it right now.
I will do it right now.
Ocorreu aqui mesmo.It happened right here.
It happened right here.
Como era seu nome mesmo?What was your name again?
What was your name again?

text: though; although (despite the fact that); despite being
examples: Mesmo sendo cedo, irei para casa.Although it is early, I will go home.
Although it is early, I will go home.
Mesmo pobre, sempre conseguiu alimentar seus filhos.Despite being poor, he was always able to feed his children.
Despite being poor, he was always able to feed his children.
Synonyms: embora, apesar de

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese esta, from Latin ista.
From Old Portuguese elles, from Latin illos, influenced by the singular form.

text: masculine third-person plural nominative personal pronoun; they
masculine third-person plural prepositional pronoun; them
(Brazil, colloquial) masculine third-person plural personal pronoun used in all positions; they; them
examples: Obviamente eles não podem mais conversar [...]Obviously they can't discuss anymore [...]
Obviously they can't discuss anymore [...]
Eles sorriram um para o outro.They smiled to each other.
They smiled to each other.
Pensei que eles fossem invisíveis.I thought that they were invisible.
I thought that they were invisible.
Eles andaram até mim.They walked towards me.
They walked towards me.
Eu gosto de conversar com eles.I enjoy talking to them
I enjoy talking to them
Um homem matou eles.A man killed them.
A man killed them.

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese nos, from Latin nōs (“we; us”), from Proto-Italic *nōs.

text: first-person plural nominative personal pronoun: we
(Brazil, colloquial, proscribed) first-person plural objective personal pronoun; us
examples: Nós estamos aqui.We are here.
We are here.
Synonyms:  a gente,  nós outros
Os pássaros voaram até nós.The birds flew towards us.
The birds flew towards us.
Ele bateu em nós!He hit us!
He hit us!

defs.etymology: Inflected form of nó (“knot”).
From Old Portuguese todos, from Latin tōtōs, accusative masculine plural of tōtus (“all; every”), from Proto-Indo-European *tewtéh₂ (“people”).

examples: Synonym: todo mundo

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese nos, from Latin nōs (“we; us”), from Proto-Italic *nōs.

examples: Ele dir-nos-ia o nome do indivíduo; Ele nos diria o nome do indivíduo.He would have told us the name of the individual.
He would have told us the name of the individual.

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese nos, clipping of enos, from en (“in”) + os (“the”).

text: Alternative form of os (third-person masculine plural objective pronoun) used as an enclitic following a verb form ending in a nasal vowel or diphthong

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese veer, from Latin vidēre, present active infinitive of videō (“to see”), from Proto-Italic *widēō (“to see”), from Proto-Indo-European *weyd- (“to know; see”).

text: ver (first-person singular present indicative vejo, past participle visto)
(transitive) to see; to observe (to perceive with one’s eyes)
(intransitive) to see (to be able to see; not to be blind or blinded)
(intransitive with que and a subclause) to see; to notice; to realise (to come to a conclusion)
(intransitive with a subclause) to check (to verify some fact or condition)
(transitive) to watch (to be part of the audience of a visual performance or broadcast)
(takes a reflexive pronoun, copulative or auxiliary with a verb in the gerund or past participle) to find oneself (to be in a given situation, especially unexpectedly)
(informal, ditransitive, with the indirect object taking para or an indirect objective pronoun) to get used when ordering something from a waiter or attendant
(intransitive, or transitive with com) to check with (to consult [someone] for information)

words: (to observe something): contemplar, enxergar, mirar, observar, olhar

examples: Vejo duas pessoas andando.I see two people walking.
I see two people walking.
Abriram uma escola para os que não veem.They've opened a school for those who cannot see.
They've opened a school for those who cannot see.
Você vê o que eu quero dizer?Do you see what I mean?
Do you see what I mean?
Eu vi que todas essas pessoas querem que eu vá embora.I saw that all these people want me to go away.
I saw that all these people want me to go away.
Veja se o jantar já está pronto.Check whether dinner is ready.
Check whether dinner is ready.
Fomos ver quando os meteorologistas achavam que ia chover.We went to check when the meteorologists thought it was going to rain.
We went to check when the meteorologists thought it was going to rain.
Fiquei a tarde inteira vendo TV.I spent the whole afternoon watching TV.
I spent the whole afternoon watching TV.
Ela veio me ver no hospital.She came to see me at the hospital.
She came to see me at the hospital.
Não acredito que mataram meu pai. Eles vão ver.I can’t believe they killed my father. They’ll pay.
I can’t believe they killed my father. They’ll pay.
Após meses gastando sem parar, João se viu enterrado em dívidas.After months spending non-stop, John found himself buried in debt.
After months spending non-stop, John found himself buried in debt.
Por favor, me vê 500g de queijo.I would like 500g of cheese, please.
I would like 500g of cheese, please.
Mandei o recepcionista ver um táxi para o meu pai.I told the receptionist to get a cab for my dad.
I told the receptionist to get a cab for my dad.
Veja com a secretária se já enviaram o document.Check with the secretary whether the document has been sent.
Check with the secretary whether the document has been sent.

defs.etymology: Borrowed from French est, from Old English ēast, from Proto-Germanic *austrą (“east”), from Proto-Indo-European *aus- (“eastern”).

text: east (one of the four principal compass points)
este m or f (plural estes, comparable)
eastern (of, situated in, or coming from the east)

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese este (displacing collateral form aqueste), from Latin iste.

text: este m (feminine esta, plural estes, feminine plural estas)
that (indicates something or someone just mentioned)
this (indicates something or someone about to be mentioned)
(of a unit of time) this (which is current)
examples: A segurança está cem vezes mais rigorosa este verão.The security is a hundred times more severe this summer.
The security is a hundred times more severe this summer.

text: este m (feminine esta,  neuter isto, plural estes, feminine plural estas)
this one (indicates something or someone nearby)
this one (indicates something or someone about to be mentioned)
(of a unit of time) this (which is current)
first-person plural (nós) present indicative of ter
second-person singular (tu) present indicative of ter
Third-person plural (eles, elas, also used with vocês?) present indicative of estar
examples: Se ao menos a gente pudesse ouvir o que estão dizendo!If at least we could hear what they're saying!
If at least we could hear what they're saying!

defs.etymology: From Old Portuguese falar, from Vulgar Latin *fāb(u)lāre, from Latin fābulārī, present infinitive of fābulor (“chat, converse”). Doublet of the borrowing fabular.

text: falar (first-person singular present indicative falo, past participle falado)
(intransitive) to speak; to talk (to say words out loud)
(by extension) to communicate by any means
(transitive with para) to tell (to convey by speech)
(transitive with de or sobre) to talk about
(transitive with de) to speak ill of
(transitive) to speak (to be able to communicate in a language)
examples: Para de falar. ― Stop talking.
Fala! ― Talk!
Fale! ― Talk!
Falamo-nos por correio. ― We communicate by mail.
Synonym: comunicar
Para de falar bobagens. ― Stop talking nonsense.
Fala bobagens. ― Talk nonsense.
Synonym: dizer
Estou falando com você ― I'm talking to you.
Synonyms: conversar, papear
Vou falar para você. ― I’m going to tell you.
Synonyms: contar, dizer, relatar
Em Portugal fala-se português.In Portugal they speak Portuguese.
In Portugal they speak Portuguese.

text: a cant, dialect or regional language.
examples: Synonym: fala
